div1.p: Owen L. W. Smith to Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.
Scarcity of Food and Water supplies.
No. 24, Consular Series, Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, Mar. 21, 1899.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit to you the intelligence, that food and water supplies are very scarce: and high proportionatily! The scarcity of food way be accounted for, first; swing to the decline in the price of coffee; the staple and principal production of the Liberian farmer. The decline, in the price of coffee, has almost paralysed the prosperity of the Republic.
Secondly; the unsettled state of affairs, between the interior tribes and the Liberian Government, has

has brought about a state of now commercial intercourse, between the former and the latter. THirdly; the prevalence of small port, among the native fishermen, has brought about a voluntary temporary quaraty between the native fish markets and the Liberian.

If a beef is to be butchered, the owner of it; propositions it out to his near relatives and friends, before it is killed. The salesman is guided by a list in parcelling out the beef, and a stranger with money in hand and the most urgent plea cannot purchase it!
Having us nor artificial water supplies; the few who have wellson their lots, are charging as high as 1 cent per gallon or two dollars per mouth for water
water! The tension may, in part, be broken, in about 6 week, as we usually have shower, in the latter part of April.
